1.text: Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth a stinking smell: so does a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdom and honor.

2.text: A wise man’s heart is at his right hand; but a fool’s heart at his left.

3.text: Yes also, when he that is a fool walks by the way, his wisdom fails him, and he said to every one that he is a fool.

4.text: If the spirit of the ruler rise up against you, leave not your place; for yielding pacifies great offenses.

5.text: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as an error which proceeds from the ruler:

6.text: Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.

7.text: I have seen servants on horses, and princes walking as servants on the earth.

8.text: He that digs a pit shall fall into it; and whoever breaks an hedge, a serpent shall bite him.

9.text: Whoever removes stones shall be hurt therewith; and he that splits wood shall be endangered thereby.

10.text: If the iron be blunt, and he do not whet the edge, then must he put to more strength: but wisdom is profitable to direct.

11.text: Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.

12.text: The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.

13.text: The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness: and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.

14.text: A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?

15.text: The labor of the foolish wearies every one of them, because he knows not how to go to the city.

16.text: Woe to you, O land, when your king is a child, and your princes eat in the morning!

17.text: Blessed are you, O land, when your king is the son of nobles, and your princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!

18.text: By much slothfulness the building decays; and through idleness of the hands the house drops through.

19.text: A feast is made for laughter, and wine makes merry: but money answers all things.

20.text: Curse not the king, no not in your thought; and curse not the rich in your bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which has wings shall tell the matter.
